learning_outcomes.description: Identify and describe key individual and contextual features, events, and processes in human development.
Critically evaluate a range of theories related to human development.

Investigate historical and cultural influences in human development, specifically regarding their impact on (a) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and (b) culturally and linguistically diverse migrant communities.
Analyse the concept of disability and examine how varying interpretations influence human development across the lifespan.
Apply a human development framework to conduct assessments, considering risks, adversities, and sources of resilience to support wellbeing across the lifespan.
Integrate critical reflexivity and cultural humility when conducting assessments within a human development framework.
Exhibit advanced written and oral communication skills and demonstrate effective independent and group collaboration abilities.

assessments.task_description:
This in-class/in-person quiz is an initial task to assess your knowledge of the foundational material covered during Weeks 1 to 3 of this course.

Your quiz is designed as a closed-book assessment containing 40 multiple-choice questions worth 0.5 marks each. 

The quiz is scheduled for Wednesday, 25 March 2026 at 12:00 pm, and must be completed within 40 minutes (plus 10 minutes reading time). As this quiz is taken in class/in person, you must attend the lecture period during which it is scheduled to be able to complete this task.

Note: Full details about the use of AI and MT for assessment tasks in this course are available on the course Blackboard site. It is essential that students familiarise themselves with those requirements.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
24/04/2026 - 14/05/2026

PowerPoint slides are due in Week 8 on Friday, 24 April 2026 at 1:00 pm;

Presentations will be conducted during the Weeks 9-11 tutorials.
assessments.task_description:
In Week 5, students will be allocated to groups for their second assessment task: Group presentation (In-class) – Case analysis. The relevant case study will be published at the start of Week 5. PowerPoint slides are due at the end of Week 8, and presentations are conducted in person during tutorial time during Weeks 9, 10, and 11.

This task requires students to work in groups of three to four to prepare and present a professional conversation about the case study provided, including your consideration of how best to support the main character in coping with past and current adversities, risks, and difficulties, promoting their strengths, and enhancing their resilience.

The conversation will be maximally 7.5 minutes per group member, that is, a total of maximally 22.5 minutes for a group of three students and 30 minutes for a group of four. Your presentation will be supported with PowerPoint slides, to which all members are expected to contribute.

Note: Full details about the use of AI and MT for assessment tasks in this course are available on the course Blackboard site. It is essential that students familiarise themselves with those requirements.
assessments.submission_guidelines: ONE nominated group member is required to submit the PowerPoint slides no later than Friday, 24 April 2026, 1:00 pm, via the Blackboard submission point provided.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This final assessment task (Exam - Quiz and Case Analysis) is a closed-book assessment of 150 minutes (plus 10 minutes reading time).

It is an opportunity for you to demonstrate your knowledge and understanding of human development as a multidimensional process and to show how it may inform social work’s contribution to enhancing human wellbeing in line with “[p]rinciples of social justice, human rights, collective responsibility, and respect for diversity” (IFSW/IASSW 2014).

To this end, your end-of-semester exam will be based on a case study, provided in Week 12, and require you to answer a set of four short-answer questions, one short essay question, and 20 multiple-choice questions. 

Note: Full details about the use of AI and MT for assessment tasks in this course are available on the course Blackboard site. It is essential that students familiarise themselves with those requirements.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to Lifespan Development / Dimensions of human development

This introductory lecture provides the foundation for the contents covered in the remainder of the semester. It comprises three parts:

  1. An overview of the course and its relevance to social work practice, including a discussion of the structure, content and assessment in the course.
  2. An introduction to Harms' (2021) multidimensional approach to human development as an overarching framework to locate, critique, and apply the theories and debates covered in this course. We also consider the importance of locating ourselves critically and reflexively in relation to the contents covered in this course.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_title: Introduction to Lifespan Development / Dimensions of human development
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to Lifespan Development / Dimensions of human development This introductory lecture provides the foundation for the contents covered in the remainder of the semester. It comprises three parts: An overview of the course and its relevance to social work practice, including a discussion of the structure, content and assessment in the course. An introduction to Harms' (2021) multidimensional approach to human development as an overarching framework to locate, critique, and apply the theories and debates covered in this course. We also consider the importance of locating ourselves critically and reflexively in relation to the contents covered in this course.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to the concept of culture

In this lecture, we examine the concept of culture and its relevance for understanding human development. We explore the intersections between the relational, social, structural, and cultural contexts of people's lives, focusing on the concepts of culture, cultural humility, safety, and responsiveness.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: Introduction to the concept of culture
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to the concept of culture In this lecture, we examine the concept of culture and its relevance for understanding human development. We explore the intersections between the relational, social, structural, and cultural contexts of people's lives, focusing on the concepts of culture, cultural humility, safety, and responsiveness.

learning_activities.topic:
Discussion, application, and critique / Assessment 1 preparation

In Week 2, we commence with our weekly two-hour tutorials. This week, we -

  1. Critically discuss the relevance, strengths and limitations of contemporary conceptualisations of culture, cultural humility, responsiveness, and safety, and their links with trauma-informed practice.
  2. Support your preparations for your first assessment task (in person/in-class quiz scheduled for Week 5).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: Discussion, application, and critique / Assessment 1 preparation
learning_activities.topic_description: Discussion, application, and critique / Assessment 1 preparation In Week 2, we commence with our weekly two-hour tutorials. This week, we - Critically discuss the relevance, strengths and limitations of contemporary conceptualisations of culture, cultural humility, responsiveness, and safety, and their links with trauma-informed practice. Support your preparations for your first assessment task (in person/in-class quiz scheduled for Week 5).

learning_activities.topic:
Stages of human development / Erikson's theory of psychosocial development

In our Week 3 lecture, we focus on the stages of human development, as conceptualised by Erik Erikson's in his theory of psychosocial development. We will consider:

  1. The origin, main tenets, applications, and critiques of Erikson's theory of psychosocial development.
  2. How the idea of developmental stages contributes to organising this course.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: Stages of human development / Erikson's theory of psychosocial development

We will consider: The origin, main tenets, applications, and critiques of Erikson's theory of psychosocial development. How the idea of developmental stages contributes to organising this course.

learning_activities.topic:
Discussion, application, and critique / Asessment 1 preparation

In Week 3, we continue with our weekly two-hour tutorials. This week, we -

  1. Critically discuss the relevance, strengths and limitations of Erik Erikson's theory of psychosocial development.
  2. Support your preparations for your first assessment task (in person/in-class quiz scheduled for Week 5).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to the concept of disability

For Week 4, we invited a guest lecturer, A/Prof Kathy Ellem, to conduct a two-hour seminar to help us examine the contested nature of health and ability. We explore definitions and models of disability and reflect on attitudes and biases impacting the health and development of people with disability. Our theoretical focus is on Dan Goodley's disability studies matrix.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04

We explore definitions and models of disability and reflect on attitudes and biases impacting the health and development of people with disability. Our theoretical focus is on Dan Goodley's disability studies matrix.

  2. Complete our preparations for your first assessment task (in person/in-class quiz scheduled for Week 5).

This in-person/in-class quiz is held during your regular lecture date and time. The venue will change, and this will be announced closer to the date.

The quiz contains 40 multiple-choice questions, covering contents from Weeks 1 to 4 of this course to test your understanding of the theoretical concepts framing this course.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
The prenatal period / Attachment theories

After the quiz, we commence our lectures on human development across the lifespan, focusing on the prenatal period and introducing attachment theories.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Discussion, application, and critique / Assessment 2 preparation begins

In this week's tutorials, we -

  1. Address any open questions concerning our lecture and online content.
  2. Critically discuss the origin, main tenets, applications, and points of critique of attachment theories.
  3. Set up your your Assessment 2 groups.
  4. Discuss the case study upon which your second assessment task will be based, as well as work through some of the common challenges in group-based assignments, including how best to resolve them.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Infancy and early childhood development / Piaget's theory of cognitive development

This lecture focuses on the developmental tasks and transitions in infancy and early childhood, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during these stages of the lifespan. Our theory in focus is Jean Piaget's theory of cognitive development.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Our theory in focus is Jean Piaget's theory of cognitive development.

learning_activities.topic:
Discussion, application and critique / Assessment 2 preparation continues

In this week's tutorial groups, we -

  1. Address any open questions concerning our lecture and online content.
  2. Critically discuss the origin, main tenets, applications, and points of critique of Piaget's theory of cognitive development.
  3. Continue your Assessment 2 preparations with an in-depth discussion of our marking rubric - also in relation to the case study provided and lecture contents from the previous weeks.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Development in middle childhood / Vygotsky's socio-cultural theory of development

This lecture examines the developmental tasks and transitions in middle childhood, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this stage of the lifespan. Theory in focus: Lev Vygotsky's sociocultural theory of cognitive development.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Development in adolescence / Kohlberg's theory of moral development

This lecture examines the developmental tasks and transitions in adolescence, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this stage of the lifespan. Our theoretical focus is on Lawrence Kohlberg's theory of moral development.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Development in young adulthood / Arnett's theory of emerging adulthood

This lecture focuses on the developmental tasks and processes associated with young adulthood, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this period of development. Our theory in focus is Arnett's theory of emerging adulthood. What does this recently proposed stage of emerging adulthood entail, and how does it compare to both adolescence and young adulthood?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Special topic: Displacement, migration, and human development

In this seminar, a mental health social worker with almost 20 years of experience in international social work and one of their service users talk about practice with refugees and asylum seekers and how people may navigate life challenges under conditions of displacement and resettlement.

We use this opportunity to return to the topics of culture, cultural humility, safety, and responsiveness to consider their links with trauma-informed practice in social work.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Special topic: Displacement, migration, and human development

We use this opportunity to return to the topics of culture, cultural humility, safety, and responsiveness to consider their links with trauma-informed practice in social work.

learning_activities.topic:
Assessment 3 (exam) preparation

In this week's tutorial groups, we -

  1. Focus on your exam preparations with an in-depth discussion of the examiner's expectations.
  2. Address any open questions concerning our lectures and online content of the previous weeks.
  3. Have an opportunity to critically discuss the theories discussed in the preceding weeks: In terms of origin, application, and points of critique, what are the similarities and differences, the overlaps and contradictions between Harms' multidimensional approach, Levinson's model, and Baltes' tenets of lifespan development?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07

learning_activities.topic:
Special topic: Social work at the end of life

While grief and loss are themes that pervade all social work practice, at the end of the semester, in this two-hour seminar, we want to consider the relevance of these themes for the end of life and for those left behind. To this end, we have invited a social worker from Queensland Health with years of experience in emergency care and cancer services to talk about her practice in supporting patients and their loved ones in coping with different forms of loss and grief.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

To this end, we have invited a social worker from Queensland Health with years of experience in emergency care and cancer services to talk about her practice in supporting patients and their loved ones in coping with different forms of loss and grief.
